title: 115_hr3629
content: The "Payroll Fraud Prevention Act of 2017" is the short title of this Act. It classifies employees and non-employees. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 has been amended to define 'Non-employee' as an individual engaged for labor or services who is not an employee. A 'Covered individual' includes employees and non-employees engaged for labor or services by an employer or person required to file an information return. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 has been amended to classify individuals engaged for labor or services as non-employees under certain conditions, including ownership interest in an entity, the entity being necessary for the provision of labor or services, and the requirement to file an information return for the entity. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 has been amended to require accurate classification of individuals as employees or non-employees engaged in commerce or production of goods. Employers must provide a notice to employees and maintain records accordingly. The Payroll Fraud Prevention Act of 2017 mandates providing a notice to covered individuals within 6 months of enactment and subsequently to new employees and non-employees upon employment. Any change in status must also be communicated in writing. The Payroll Fraud Prevention Act of 2017 requires written notice to covered individuals, informing them of their classification as an employee or non-employee, directing them to the Department of Labor website for more information, providing contact information for the local Department of Labor office, and stating the rights of non-employees regarding wages, hours, and labor. The Payroll Fraud Prevention Act of 2017 mandates written notice to individuals about their classification as an employee or non-employee. Failure to provide this notice presumes the individual as an employee. Contact the U.S. Department of Labor for any classification concerns. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 prohibits discrimination against individuals who oppose certain practices or file complaints related to their employment status. This includes individuals classified as employees or non-employees under the Act. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 prohibits discrimination against individuals based on their employment status, including misclassification of employees as non-employees. Amendments include penalties for misclassification, recordkeeping, and notice violations. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 prohibits discrimination based on employment status, including misclassification of employees. Penalties for misclassification, recordkeeping, and notice violations are included. Liquidated damages are doubled for non-compliance by covered individuals. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 prohibits discrimination based on employment status and includes penalties for misclassification, recordkeeping, and notice violations. Liquidated damages are doubled for non-compliance by covered individuals, with civil penalties imposed for violations of specific sections. The Secretary of Labor will create a webpage summarizing employee rights under the Fair Labor Standards Act within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Additionally, there will be measures to address misclassification of employees for unemployment compensation purposes. The Social Security Act is amended to include auditing procedures to identify non-compliant employers and establish penalties for misclassifying employees or paying unreported wages. The Secretary of Labor will review auditing programs. The Secretary of Labor will review auditing programs to measure States' effectiveness in identifying underreported wages and unemployment compensation contributions. The amendments made by subsection (a) will take effect 12 months after enactment, with exceptions for states needing legislative changes for compliance. The term "State" in this section refers to the definition in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 5. DEPARTMENT OF LABOR COORDINATION, REFERRAL, AND REGULATIONS. The Department of Labor offices must report any information on misclassification under the Fair Labor Standards Act to the Wage and Hour Division. The Division may share this information with the IRS. The Secretary of Labor will create regulations for this Act. SEC. 6. TARGETED AUDITS. SEC. 6. TARGETED AUDITS. Audits of employers under the Fair Labor Standards Act will focus on industries prone to misclassifying employees as non-employees, as determined by the Secretary of Labor.
